title: Razgrad
text:
Razgrad ( ) is a <a href="city">city</a> in Northeastern Bulgaria in the valley of the <a href="Rusenski%20Lom">Beli Lom</a> river that falls within the historical and geographical region of <a href="Ludogorie">Ludogorie</a>. It is an administrative center of <a href="Razgrad%20Province">Razgrad Province</a>.
Etymology.
The suffix "grad" means city in <a href="Bulgarian%20language">Bulgarian</a>, while the origin and the meaning of the first part "raz" is obscure. 
During the <a href="Second%20Bulgarian%20Empire">Second Bulgarian Empire</a>, around the present city there was a settlement, mentioned by the names of "Hrasgrad", "Hrazgrad" and "Hrizgrad"'. These names come from the name of the <a href="Bulgars">Bulgar</a> and Slavic god <a href="Hors%20%28deity%29">Hors</a>.
History.
Razgrad was built upon the ruins of the <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Ancient Roman</a> town of <a href="Abritus">Abritus</a> on the banks of the <a href="%D0%91%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%20%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%BC%20%28%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0%29">Beli Lom</a> river. Abritus was built on a <a href="Thracians">Thracian</a> settlement of the 4th-5th century BC of unknown name. Several bronze coins of the Thracian king <a href="Seuthes%20III">Seuthes III</a> (330-300 BC) and pottery were found, as well as artifacts from other rulers and a sacrificial altar of <a href="Hercules">Hercules</a>.
Some of Razgrad's landmarks include the Varosha architectural complex from the 19th century, the ethnographic museum and several other museums, the characteristic <a href="clock%20tower">clock tower</a> in the centre built in 1864, the <a href="St%20Nicholas">St Nicholas</a> the Miracle Worker Church from 1860, the "Momina cheshma" sculpture, the Mausoleum Ossuary of the Liberators (1879–1880) and the <a href="Ibrahim%20Pasha%20Mosque">Ibrahim Pasha Mosque</a> from 1530. The mosque is said to be one of the largest in the Balkans.
In 251, the town was the site of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Abrittus">Battle of Abrittus</a>, during which the <a href="Goths">Goths</a> defeated a <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman</a> army under the emperors <a href="Trajan%20Decius">Trajan Decius</a> and <a href="Herennius%20Etruscus">Herennius Etruscus</a>. The battle is notable for being the first occasion of a Roman emperor being killed in a battle with barbarians.
<a href="Razgrad%20Peak">Razgrad Peak</a> on <a href="Greenwich%20Island">Greenwich Island</a> in the <a href="South%20Shetland%20Islands">South Shetland Islands</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a> is named after Razgrad.
Population.
In January 2012, Razgrad was inhabited by 33,416 people within the city limits, while the <a href="Razgrad%20Municipality">Razgrad Municipality</a> with the legally affiliated adjacent villages had 50,457 inhabitants. The <a href="Razgrad%20Province">Razgrad Province</a> has the second largest <a href="Turks%20in%20Bulgaria">Turkish population in Bulgaria</a> behind the <a href="Kardzhali%20Province">Kardzhali Province</a>, though the municipality and the city of Razgrad have a lower proportion of Turks than the rest of the province.
Sport.
Razgrad is widely recognizable for being home to the association football club <a href="Ludogorets%20Razgrad">Ludogorets Razgrad</a>, who in recent years have become the dominant force in Bulgarian football after winning ten consecutive <a href="First%20Professional%20Football%20League%20%28Bulgaria%29">Bulgarian First League</a> titles between 2012 and 2021. After reaching the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a> round of 16 during the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2013–14 season</a>, the club also made their <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> debut appearance <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">a season later</a>. Ludogorets play their home matches at <a href="Ludogorets%20Arena">Ludogorets Arena</a>, a venue with a capacity for 10,500 people.
